description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ilaFw99wcWC

I've been fortunate to have a little time this summer to work on a project or two that are less than mission critical, while still being potentially useful...case in point a custom chess set design that I'd like to make available to support our engineering program, and would like student assistants to be able to manufacture for me. I'd finished the lathe programs for all the pieces and only had the slot in the bishop's mitre and the knight's nose to finish and was wondering how to make it simple. It occurred to me that amongst all the designs that are parametric and flexible for many situations, one of the strengths of 3D printing is to make that single, one-off, ultra custom, just-for-one-purpose piece.
So, here are the custom machining jig parts that simplify finishing the bishop and knight pieces for my custom designed chess pieces.
I used Solidworks to design the pieces and modeled the machining jigs by boolean subtraction.

title: Medication Bottle Opener
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
update 6/21/16 Meeting with express scripts Thursday with a slightly different prototype to see about getting this on the market. Will make a more updated update afterwards update 2/25/16 so apparently this was considered cool by some people and it got mentioned in this article: http://www.edtechmagazine.com/k12/article/2016/02/student-3d-printing-designs-help-those-disabilities-tackle-daily-tasks and http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2016/02/15/5-student-designs-that-prove-3d-printing-is-reshaping-education.
If you want I can post a video demo of how to use it, just say so in comments So my father has MS, due to this, one of the small nuances he has is opening regular pill bottles. Now rather than making dozens of new pill bottles for him, I decided I'll start working on making a tool to help him open the freak'n bottle. In the new version it works with the 90 day bottles as well. It works by gripping either the bottom or the top of bottles. Personally I think it works best placed on a table with the bottle your trying to open on top of it.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

lower is better

Infill:

15-20%

Notes: A thicker layer height helps it grip the bottle better, however a lower layer height feels smoother, I guess it is a matter of personal preference and time your have. On .3 mm it can be printed in just over an hour.

Mock Ups So I designed this first mockup using inventor since that's what I'm learning in high school. I've made most of it parametricly relying heavily off the dimension of the pill bottle, hopefully I can learn openscad in time to try making a customizer version. In the second mockup I changed to a handle design based off of feedback that some disabled people may not be able to grasp their hand all the way, however it would be possible for them to still use a lever. Another small experimental feature I added was a second ring inside for tackling smaller pill bottle caps. mockup 1 mockup 2 for mockup 3 all I did was change that dimension from 1.5 to 1.475 'final' model This was designed using a series of extrusions in inventor, then filleting them for more grip. After getting feedback from Venture Cafe, where someone with a broken had tried to use it, I decided that the lever is a must. It allows people to place their bottle on the opener, then well open it with just one working hand. (will add more about this later)

Displayed the Product at Venture Cafe So Yesterday (10/23/15) I showed the medication bottle opener off at the venture cafe to get some user feedback, and I'm shocked that I had no negative feedback! There were several sales reps who now want to give my product to their clients (for Free!) to make life easier on them. Decided I should probably get back to the injection mold guys about getting one of those so this would cost less than $1 per unit. Thanks for inspiring me to create this product, hope it helps a lot of people.
http://www.vencafstl.org/event/product-demo-spark-techology-soultions/?instance_id=16659#. Now with a no handle option There is a no handle option for the uncapper mockup 2 now. As a small note, after the competition I'll make the license more open, just would prefer no remakes before then. Additional Resources One thing if you do not have to worry about having non 'child proof' lids is to just ask your pharmacist for easy open pill bottles, most carriers have some form of arthritis friendly containers.

title: Greg's Hinged Accessible Extruder with arcol.hu support

description.text:
I add arcol.hu hotend support for Greg's Hinged Accessible Extruder.
This is my first ever try with openscad.
So the code maybe not the most optimal.
Here it is the version 2 of extruder block with arcol hot-end support. I have widened the base in the middle, to not allow any movement for the arcol hot-end.
Version 2 is untested! As I did not have the time to print it yet.
The stl file is for arcol.hu hotend. The scad file can be set to any other supported head type.

comments.text: When I was incorporating this mount option, I noticed that you only use 2 of what looks like 3 mounting holes on the arcol. Why not put the 2 holes on the other side and add support for the 3rd hole? Using 2, the hotend will likely wobble around as the feed pressure varies?
comments.author: GregFrost

comments.text: I'm testing this design with arcol hot end for a while. Greg you are right I have some issues because of the two mounting holes. arcol hot-end has 3 little legs what should be hold it stable against the extruder block. But because this extruder block is thinner then the original. the third leg is in the air. what can cause the hot end to tilt a few degree. If I size the base of the extruder block 4mm wider that would fix the issue. So version 2 coming soon.
comments.author: GregFrost

comments.text: There is only two mounting holes on my http://arcol.huarcol.hu hotend. I don't have any wobble.

Hello
I must apologize for my long overdue response. My life has been a bit crazy. The thing that clicked on is just images of the final assembly. The actual files are available but are in the form of parts groups. The parts are all designed in full scale and will have to be scaled down to print. My current project is a 750 hp triple expansion marine steam engine. It is by far the most complicated project thus far. I plan to publish it this year. My solid works program estimates it's total weight without condenser or thrust block at around 1000 kilos. I'll share images of the progressing work if you are interested

comments.author: brilant1

comments.text: Looks great is this from a real engine?  What is the manufacturer? can I get solidworks files for this?
comments.author: brilant1

comments.text: A sdlprt file is a Solidworks part file.  To use this file you need a copy of Solidworks.  Sadly there is no free version, and the paid version is quite expensive.
comments.author: Skimbal

comments.text: there is a free version, it's called onshape (it's nearly identical to solidworks but it's web-based). and yes it is compatible with .sldprt files.
comments.author: Skimbal

comments.text: sdlprt is a makerbot specific file, I think that if you download it and change the extensions to zip it become a zip archive, I will try this out.

title: Dremel Flex Shaft Model 225 Tool mount for Lulzbot TAZ printers.

description.text:
The basic concept here is to allow the connection of a reasonably beefy spindle motor for PCB milling on the TAZ. Since the gantry would suffer under the weight of the spindle motor, we use a Dremel 225 Flex Shaft to connect to the remotely mounted motor. This component secures the hand tool of the 225 in a TAZ compatible modular tool mount. This is a pretty quick and simple remix of the the tool blank here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:637670
and the 225 Pen mount from a Prusa here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:264104

title: Printrbot Play Heated Bed Upgrade to Printrbot Simple Metal Converter

description.text:
Use these brackets to mount the Printrbot Play Heated bed upgrade to the Simple Metal. You will not lose any X or Y area, but you will lose a little Z.
Print both the Inside and Outside brackets, but invert the second pair. The Inside brackets will connect closest to the body of the printer.
I had to drill sink holes into mic6 bed so that the screws were flush. If you don't, you may have issues with the z-sensor and fan shroud hitting the screws. You'll also need to get shorter screws for the mic6 bed because the screws that come with the upgrade kit are too long. I could have made the brackets thicker to accommodate the screws, but I didn't want to give up any more Z.
Use the existing screws on the original bed to fasten the brackets to the printer.

description.text: Just give your printer a tiny printing fun :)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

This is a plastic enclosure for RETRO Innovation's uIEC CBM floppy disk drive emulator card for the Commodore 64. It has been designed to enclose the uIEC and its deluxe daughtercard in their L-shaped configuration. It is a pretty narrow fit, with supports to prevent the electronics inside from moving around too much when it is being plugged into the cassette port of the C64. It has 4 holes, one for the dataset connector, another one for the IEC cables, one for the SD card and one above the four control buttons on the uIEC card. It also has a little support (the tail of the bunny) which slides below the C64 to prevent the mechanical force which would be forcing the whole dataset connector upwards because of the layout of the uIEC card itself. It has been designed for the C64-i (the classic model), I don't know if it is needed and if works with the C64-ii at all. UPDATE:
Added the model files for the buttons and their little box which can be used to access the 4 buttons (fwd, back, swap, reset) on the circuit. UPDATE:
Updated the files so that the SVG files are easier to edit.

If you can, print it with 0.2mm layer height. If you use a lower height, there will be infill and it will take a lot longer to print.   
I sliced it with Slic3r, it did a pretty terrible job, artifacts everywhere, but it worked.   
The top and bottom parts need to be glued together after the electronics have been inserted. You will need to break the whole thing to get the electronics out. There's still room for improvement here :)  
If you want to use the 4 little buttons on the circuit (used for changing disks), print the button cage and 4 buttons as well. The cage itself fits tightly into the hole on the back of the rabbit.

description.text: I just bought a ten-pack of PLA, so I could finally print this design.  To make this stellation of the icosahedron you need 60 of these pieces.  I printed them in 10 groups of six, each group a different color.  Because this is a stellation of the icosahedron, the faces fall on twenty planes.  Each plane contains 3 of the faces.  Ideally it would be cool to print 20 different colors, but each plane has a parallel plane that will never be seen at the same time.  So we can get away with just 10 colors.  The five pieces that make each point snap together with a bit of coaxing.  Then the 12 points snap together at their bases.  This is easier said that done.  I had to resort to using glue so that it would not fall apart as I was trying to get the last pieces in.  It would have been much easier if I had 12 hands.  Alas - I do not.

comments.text: I wish I could give this 10000 likes
comments.author: mathgrrl

comments.text: Thanks.  But to be honest. Getting the last two points in was sufficiently frustrating to prompt a redesign.  I'll post it when I get it done.
comments.author: mathgrrl

title: Resized LED tea light holder for LED Skull Lantern

description.text:
I'm using some inexpensive LED tea lights, and they're smaller than the ones the LED Skull Lantern was designed for. They move around quite a bit, so I redrew the part, and moved the pegs closer to the middle to hold them more stable. The space between the pegs should be about 1.2" in diameter (depending on how fast you print it and how neatly it comes out). 
The original was closer to 1.5", so you might want to measure your lights to see which one will fit yours best. 
EDIT 10-25-15:  The original version of this was smaller than I intended. I put the center points of the pegs where the edges should have been, and it turned out smaller than I wanted. The new version will have the proper gap, and be about 1.2 inches in diameter. The first version was closer to 1 inch even.

title: Quick Exchange MK8 Extruder + Inductive Sensor Mount for PROXXON Tool Holder

description.text:
I made this bracket to be able to plug an MK8 extruder into the PROXXON/Dremel Mount of the Mostly Printed CNC. It mounts and unmounts as quickly as the spindle or the laser, making tool changes easier.
This thing should hold many extruders (at least the MKx series) since it was designed to "hug" a NEMA17 stepper. It also features a bore for 12mm inductive sensors as a Z endstop.
All that is needed is a 20mm M4 bolt with a hex nut.

description.text: This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:882810 . Thanks to djui for providing the Antimony source file so I could modify it.

The original version was made for the 42mm version of the Apple Watch, however I always needed to lift my Apple Watch a bit when in the stand so that it will be charged. Therefore I've modified the original design so that the 38mm version fits well.
I made the cable channels a bit larger to also fit my charging cable. It could be even a bit larger than in my modified design.

I was always afraid I could not remove the charger from the dock once it's plugged in. To overcome this anxiety I added a slot from the bottom that is invisible and can be used to remove the charger cable.

If you look at my pictures you see three designs:
  • the one by djui
  • my first modification with a charger removal slot
  • the final version optimized for my 38mm Apple Watch and a larger removal slot
    • Tip for printing: The first version by djui I printed with more infill, so it's a bit heavier. My later versions are too lightweight and if I'd reprint them I'd use more infill again. Since Antimony creates huge STL files which I couldn't print I then post processed the 100MB STL file using MeshLab so that it could be printed and now its 3.5MB in size. I also added the Antimony source files again to keep the spirit of sharing.

Now a 42mm version of the final STL file is also available. I simplified the STL quite a bit, so you can leave a comment if a version with more faces is needed, but you can also use Antimony to create a highly detailed version. I also forgot to mention that the STL files went through netfabb in order to remove any model errors, if any.
Have fun!

http://gadgets.boingboing.net/2009/03/23/how-to-cut-credit-ca.html
http://blog.makezine.com/archive/2009/03/credit-card-iphone-stand.html?CMP=OTC-0D6B48984890

description.text:
This is actually a test object for the disk shooter contest. I don't have a 3d printer, and was wondering about a few different things to see how well they print. This actually consists of 3 pieces that are put together. This was designed for 19 mm by 2 mm disks. The disks.stl file just contains 16 disks that should be the right size. I tried to give a little space around objects, so I definitely want to know how that works out when printed. I also designed the bottom and top to interlock together. They won't snap together, so much as fit together with tabs and slots. If you print this for me, I'd be very very happy! I also want to know the design flaws of this. This is a WIP because I'm trying to make it have a cartridge to hold the disks. There are two modifiable variables in the OpenSCAD document. "l" (lowercase L) is the length of the disk shooter. It is currently set at 100 for 100mm.
"num" is the number of tabs used to put the bottom and top pieces together. Really, all that does is define the spacing for it, as some tabs aren't fully there because of the hole in the top piece to load the shooter. The default is 10, but in this case, only 8 are technically visible. Also, the minimum working number is 1, the maximum is 20. Please post pictures and give tips if you print this, or if you just know how to use openSCAD better than I do. Thank you!

There are 3 pieces to this. There is the bottom, the top, and the plunger. This object is 100 mm x 100 mm basically, so it should just barely fit on a makerbot platform. (Note that you do not need to rotate any piece)
1) Put the bottom and top together with the slots. (make sure the hole in the top is on the opposite side of the part of the bottom where the rubber bands will go)
2) Either glue them together or tape around the pieces.
3) Put the plunger into the slot, inserting on the side with the hole.
4) Take 2 rubber bands, and put them on each side, attaching one end of the band to the bottom (at the end where the slots are, away from the hole in the top piece) and attaching the other end to the plunger.
5) Load a disk (currently can only fire one at a time, again, this is a WIP to see if it's printable)
6) Pull the plunger back enough to let the disk fall in place, and release to fire.

comments.text: Well... If you're looking add the cartridge for holding discs... I've got some preliminary designs on that too! This one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10328http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... uses the spring and slide from a Pez dispenser to advance the discs. It's got a design for a removable cartridge that works pretty well. If you poke around the OpenSCAD design, you'll see how the cartridge is designed to pop up into the barrel of a disc shooter - so that the firing pin can hit the topmost disc. There's a cutout in the top of the cartridge to allow the discs to be held at a specific height to ensure the firing pin will always hit.
comments.author: jnesselr

comments.text: I take it that big lever-like thing behind the trigger is a doozy to do?
comments.author: MakerBlock

comments.text: Probably not? Really it's that I'm not the world's best 3D designer. I've got a few prototypes that work. This one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9829http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... does much the same as graphmastur's version above. What I discovered is that it was easier to print with just a few notches, and then print a part that would slide over the front of the barrel. If that part that slides over the front of the barrel is where the rubber bands fit, then it would naturally want to hold itself together. The problem with just relying on notches, at least in my testing, is that the rubber bands put the parts under a lot of force - and can twist the plastic causing the parts to be pulled out of alignment or the slide in the barrel to develop a curve. I also included a small curved area - so that the discs don't slide back into the shooter. I haven't done enough testing to be sure, but I believe there may be a benefit to hitting the disc more on one side than the other - in order to impart a little spin.

title: Simple J Head Extruder Mount for Ormerod

description.text:
With Cheap J Head Exstruders available on Ebay and the like I'm currently trialing a £7 J Head on the Ormerod(1). The mount is designed to mount the J Head and 40mm Cooling Fan to the existing X carriage. The design also includes the mounting for the Z axis micro switch I use for zeroing the Z axis on my Ormerod. The switch mount is part of the Clamp that remains in place on the X carriage, so doesn't require re-setting when changing the J head for any reason. As the Z axis microswitch is triggered by the tilt of the exstruder when it touches the Glass Bed, any thickness of glass can be used on the bed (as and when) without having to re-calibrate the switch. This is a trial setup, in preparation for conversion to a Duel exstruder. I am also trying to source a suitable 6 pin miniature power connector for use with the mount. A further revision (available shortly) will include a mount for a 12V LED indicator to show when the Heater is active.
Notes I meant to add.... There are two cable tie points. One for the wiring of the microswitch, and the other for the HotEnd wiring. I will be adding some more, when I decide on a suitable 6pin connector.

title: Holster for Panasonic DMC-GM1 Camera and Acronym / Bagjack Messenger Bags

description.text: This is a quick draw horizontal holster for the Panasonic Lumix DMC-GM1 camera with a small prime lens mounted, intended to be used inside an Acronym or Bagjack messenger bag with the velcro strip-lined inner tarp "bucket". The holster floats above whatever other stuff you have in the bag, meaning that it's not only covered from the elements but it's also easy to extract. You'll need adhesive Velcro tabs in addition to this. Attach the correct-side velcro strip to the outside of the foot to align with the velcro strip on the bag, slide the foot in, press down on the Velcro to attach. The clearance is enough for the Leica DG 15mm. The popular 20mm F1.7 pancake fits fine, as does of course the kit lens. Apologies for the general lack of sexy fillets but it prints totally fine. Provided your printer has decent bridging capabilities you should not need any supports for this - the transition between the foot and the body is appropriately stepped.

author: Dim3nsion

description.text: I needed something to store my external HDD's in. This container is 176mm (H) x 102mm (W) x 112mm (D). It can be divided up into 6 different compartments (27mm x 98mm x 110mm). Each compartment has it's own slide in divider, so you don't necessarily have to have 6 compartments (anywhere from 1 to 6). I designed it to be assembled (as I was trying to cut down on print material & time required). The interlocking joints are pretty tight so using glue is an option, but not a necessity.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard

Notes: Printed on my Dremel Idea Builder at Standard resolution. You will need to print 2 smsdg-leftright_sides, 2 smsdg-topbottom, and as many smsdg-divider as you need (up to 5). Total print time for me was 12.6 hours and used 93.5m PLA.
Just print and snap together. If you don't want 6 individual compartments, don't print 5 dividers. Just print as many as you need.

The first one I designed was a single-print container. The print time was almost 24 hours and it used 105.5m of PLA. I decided that it was too long to print and wanted to cut down time and material, so I designed one that could be assembled (and customized slightly). The idea for the joints came from another project I saw on line: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1050205. I printed the Google Cardboard and liked how the joints fit together, so I decided to recreate the same type of joints in my project.

I have just started to build a Core-XY printer (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1003119) and one of the jobs I need to do is tap a 6mm thread into the end of a number of the 2020 extrusion pieces. Tapping is an easy task - as long as the thread is started straight and true. To help with this task I designed this little guide. Just slip it over the end of the extrusion and use the guide hole to keep the tap upright and on-centre. It was designed in OpenSCAD: the source file has various parameters that can be changed according to the exact dimensions of your 2020 extrusion and the hole you wish to tap. The design can easily be changed for other sizes of extrusion, but you will have to work out the position of the hole for yourself! Apologies for not including a picture of the finished tapping guide - I made one in black PLA, and it's impossible to take a useful picture of it! The Thingiview viewer will give a very clear idea of its shape.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: This is a very simple item - just use your favourite slicer to rotate it 180 degrees so that the top flat surface is on the bed, and print away using whatever plastic you prefer. If you look at the SCAD file you will see a variable called "fiddle_factor" - everybody's printer prints fractionally different sizes, so this factor allows the user to make sure that the tapping guide is an easy fit on the extrusion without being too loose. Don't get too hung up about the fit, as anything that gets the tap close to vertical will do the job.

Using the tapping guide Slip the guide over the end of the extrusion, insert the tap and create 3 or 4 turns of thread (remembering to cut a half-turn, then go back a quarter turn or so to clear the metal chips). Once you have made those threads you can take the guide away as the tap will run true from then on.

title: 3dpBurner2 voltage/current Meter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Simple box for a voltage/current meter. I designed this for the 3dpBurner2 3D printed laser cutter/engraver ( http://www.3dpburner.blogspot.com ), but it can be used for any other project. Print on STL position without supports. I use it on the 12v main power line. I dont like the idea to use on the laser side due the meter can contain capacitors and could spikes the diode. It´s ready to be fixed by using M3 stuff, double side tape or hot glue (i use double side foamy tape). The meter i used comes with thin red and black wires and thick red, black and yellow wires.
See pictures for assembling (on some others the yellow wire comes blue instead). Take care, usually there are two meter types with similar aspect, one for direct measuring 0-10A (this one) and another for measuring 10-100A where an external shunt is a need (not suitable for 3dpBurner consumption <10A) There is a similar but temperature meter here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1419583 UPDATED 16/MAR/2016 Added new version "meterVolCur.STL", the recommended one to print.

  • Open .SCAD file and modify variables for your particular button

  • Print with full support (also probably enable raft)
  • Finish by hand
  • Cook yummy foods!

  • Download .stl of interest
  • Flip and position on your build platform with ReplicatorG etc. as desired.
  • Print with full support (also probably enable raft)
  • Finish by hand
  • Cook yummy foods!

Between the stand and base, I recommend using an outdoor type double-sided tape and cable tie to secure.
Between each layer, center of the connecting rods are hollow all the way through, so I recommend to use a long cable tie or a piece a wire to tied it down. If you like my design, please leave a like and support and follow! Thanks!

title: Adjustable Solar Panel Mount w/ Control Box Mount

description.text:
For this project I needed to make an adjustable mount for our solar panel in order to easily change the angle of the panel in relation to the sun. I used this iPad mount from amazon. http://www.amazon.com/EMPIRE-Adjustable-Flexible-Extension-Mount/dp/B005VSHMSY/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1371562742&sr=8-1&keywords=ipad+flexible+arm+stand Solar Panel
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005LR9IOG/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 First, I made a backing out of 1/4" plywood using a laser cutter to match the exact dimensions of the solar panel. Then I cut 4 holes to put printable rivets into the holes to secure the panel to the backing. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:79580 I then added clips in each corner to hold the panel even more securely to the backing. Finally, I added the flexible iPad stand to the backing using the mount provided above. The last piece I needed was a way to mount the solar panel control box to our outdoor Coleman 13 x 13 canopy. I added three neodymium magnets to the inside of the Control Box Mount. These three magnets held the control box tightly again the canopy for 4 complete days without budging. I highly recommend this solar charger as well. We used the panel and a 12v marine deep cycle battery to run 3- 12 inch fans while charging 2 iphones for 4 days in a row. The battery never lost its charge.
